awd_titl_txt: Engineering New REU Approaches to Challenges in MultiTERM
awd_abstract_narration:
This three year Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site program, Engineering New REU Approaches to Challenges in MultiTERM at the Wake Forest Institute for Regenerative Medicine (WFIRM), will provide research opportunities at the interface of engineering and biology in challenging areas of tissue engineering and regenerative medicine (TERM) to a diverse cohort of undergraduate students from underrepresented groups with limited access to research facilities. The proposed research projects span multiple physiological systems (cardiovascular, musculoskeletal, urological, and endocrine), providing REU students a unique opportunity to become highly skilled problem solvers by appreciating generalized, system-independent approaches with many of the projects identified as high priority by NSF and DoD. Despite early successes, four main challenges remain spanning: 1) biomaterials, 2) cell sources, 3) vascularization and 4) enabling technologies such as cell delivery devices, 3D bioprinting and tissue bioreactors.  REU projects will help address these challenges. 

WFIRM will host 10 undergraduate students over 10 summer weeks where they will engage in highly interdisciplinary and challenging areas of TERM research. Outcome objectives of the program emphasize: 1) development of interest and excitement for team-based-studies and advanced education;  2) skill transference and hands-on exposure to modern instrumentation and techniques as well as rigorous analysis; 3) enhanced verbal and written communication skills emphasizing abilities to communicate across disciplines in lay and technical terms and in formally presenting in writing (for the scientific literature) and speaking (for scientific meetings); and, ultimately, 4) to initiate socialization into the very important process of growth from dependent to independent researcher status. The REU experience is supplemented with additional program elements and education on the research process, hands-on instrumentation training, workshops on bioethics and responsible conduct of research, effective oral and written communications workshops, professional development and career opportunities topics.  To increase program impact and sense of community, REU participants will also participate in non-research and outreach activities at WFIRM and with URM partners, providing forums to discuss implications of STEM advances to the larger society, while fostering networking with other students, engineers, scientists and educators. All students will present their research findings several times over the summer and in oral and poster format at a final research day event.  Opportunities to attend and present at local and national meetings is also emphasized.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit:    A significant challenge in the tissue engineering and regenerative medicine (TERM) field is developing the next generation science and engineering workforce, cognizant of the multidisciplinary challenges and approaches needed to solve TERM problems. Engineers need to understand the biological dimensions of their work to advance their engineering knowledge and interact knowledgeably with biologically trained counterparts and vice versa.   With concomitant interest in addressing the perseverance of the leaky pipeline negatively impacting diversity of the STEM workforce, we focus on enhancing participation and interest of under-represented minority (URM) groups, women, and non-traditional students.   Toward this end, the new MultiTERM REU site at the Wake Forest Institute for Regenerative Medicine (WFIRM) has been successful in engaging a diverse cohort of  30 undergraduates to summer research experiences (2018, 2019 and 2021) in multidisciplinary, team-based research at the interface of engineering and biology focused on challenging areas of TERM.  We defined specific program participant goals as > 50% from URM groups, students attending colleges with limited access to research, first generation students, early access and > 50% women. 

A novel program aspect relates to WFIRM's multidisciplinary, team-based approach to TERM research and open spaces, where faculty mentors and the entire WFIRM team share the same spaces, equipment and personnel allowing for a multi-tiered family of faculty and near-peer mentors and simultaneous exposure to TERM research projects and challenges outside their individual REU project.  Their experience is supplemented with additional program elements and education on the research process, hands-on instrumentation, workshops on bioethics, responsible conduct of research, effective oral and written communication, professional development, and career opportunities across academic, government and industry sectors.  We also include an introductory TERM fundamentals course, led by WFIRM members and global leaders in the field, to familiarize students with the essentials and challenges within the TERM field, seminars on hot topics, GRE-prep support and ongoing mentoring post the summer REU.   All students present their research findings several times over the summer in oral and poster format at a final research day event.  To further increase program impact and sense of community, students attend non-research and outreach activities, providing forums to discuss implications of STEM advances  to  the  larger  society,  while  fostering  networking with  other  students,  engineers,  scientists, educators, and businessmen. Opportunities to attend and present at national meetings are also emphasized.  Each REU participant contributed to an integral piece of research.  The primary goals of the program focused on:

  • Development of interest and excitement for team-based studies and advanced education
  • Fostering skill transference and hands-on exposure to modern instrumentation, techniques, and rigorous analysis methods
  • Providing dissemination and opportunities to enhance communication skills
  • Initiate process of growth from dependent to independent status by working as a team member in a highly multidisciplinary research environment

Broader Impacts:  Ultimately, this REU's broader impact is about empowering students with confidence, experience, and skills necessary to successfully prepare for and excel in graduate education and careers. By providing students opportunities to engage in highly multidisciplinary and challenging areas of TERM research, we can better prepare the next generation of STEM talent needed to solve our most difficult problems and threats to our nation and the globe.  

The REU projects have advanced fundamental understanding of TERM addressing engineering and biological challenges spanning 1) biomaterials for TERM and 3-D printed biomaterials; 2) cell sources, including developing and characterizing cellular therapies, 3) optimization of vascularization and incorporation of constructs into pre-vascularized structures 4) enabling technologies such as cell delivery devices, body-on-a-chip devices, and tissue bioreactors.  Our team-based approach of REU-students with faculty and near-peer graduate mentors, giving poster and oral presentations, additional program elements, including developing a scientific hypothesis, emphasis on scientific communications, responsible conduct of research, professional development with GRE-prep and networking across sectors, help REU students gain a globalized perspective of real-world applications and the critical skills needed to develop into a "research scientist".  The new MultiTERM REU site has been extremely successful in the recruitment of qualified undergraduates with 73% of REU participants being women and 63% identified as under-represented minorities. In addition, 63% were early access REU participants (e.g., 7 freshman and 12 sophomores), 25% came from institutions where research opportunities are limited and 20% as first-generation college. All  presented their research in three formats:  1) poster; 2) written and 3) oral presentation at final research symposium with 60% who have presented at professional meetings and/or published their findings in peer-reviewed journals leading to a broad dissemination of new knowledge created in the undergraduate research projects. Another broader impact is that 80% of our participants who have completed their undergraduate program, are currently attending/pursuing a graduate degree in STEM disciplines with all reporting ongoing strong interest in the TERM field and multidisciplinary, team-based research.

 


Last Modified: 01/28/2022
Modified by: Joan Schanck

Intellectual Merit:    A significant challenge in the tissue engineering and regenerative medicine (TERM) field is developing the next generation science and engineering workforce, cognizant of the multidisciplinary challenges and approaches needed to solve TERM problems. Engineers need to understand the biological dimensions of their work to advance their engineering knowledge and interact knowledgeably with biologically trained counterparts and vice versa.   With concomitant interest in addressing the perseverance of the leaky pipeline negatively impacting diversity of the STEM workforce, we focus on enhancing participation and interest of under-represented minority (URM) groups, women, and non-traditional students.   Toward this end, the new MultiTERM REU site at the Wake Forest Institute for Regenerative Medicine (WFIRM) has been successful in engaging a diverse cohort of  30 undergraduates to summer research experiences (2018, 2019 and 2021) in multidisciplinary, team-based research at the interface of engineering and biology focused on challenging areas of TERM.  We defined specific program participant goals as > 50% from URM groups, students attending colleges with limited access to research, first generation students, early access and > 50% women. 

A novel program aspect relates to WFIRM's multidisciplinary, team-based approach to TERM research and open spaces, where faculty mentors and the entire WFIRM team share the same spaces, equipment and personnel allowing for a multi-tiered family of faculty and near-peer mentors and simultaneous exposure to TERM research projects and challenges outside their individual REU project.  Their experience is supplemented with additional program elements and education on the research process, hands-on instrumentation, workshops on bioethics, responsible conduct of research, effective oral and written communication, professional development, and career opportunities across academic, government and industry sectors.  We also include an introductory TERM fundamentals course, led by WFIRM members and global leaders in the field, to familiarize students with the essentials and challenges within the TERM field, seminars on hot topics, GRE-prep support and ongoing mentoring post the summer REU.   All students present their research findings several times over the summer in oral and poster format at a final research day event.  To further increase program impact and sense of community, students attend non-research and outreach activities, providing forums to discuss implications of STEM advances  to  the  larger  society,  while  fostering  networking with  other  students,  engineers,  scientists, educators, and businessmen. Opportunities to attend and present at national meetings are also emphasized.  Each REU participant contributed to an integral piece of research.  The primary goals of the program focused on:

Development of interest and excitement for team-based studies and advanced education
Fostering skill transference and hands-on exposure to modern instrumentation, techniques, and rigorous analysis methods
Providing dissemination and opportunities to enhance communication skills
Initiate process of growth from dependent to independent status by working as a team member in a highly multidisciplinary research environment


Broader Impacts:  Ultimately, this REU's broader impact is about empowering students with confidence, experience, and skills necessary to successfully prepare for and excel in graduate education and careers. By providing students opportunities to engage in highly multidisciplinary and challenging areas of TERM research, we can better prepare the next generation of STEM talent needed to solve our most difficult problems and threats to our nation and the globe.

Our team-based approach of REU-students with faculty and near-peer graduate mentors, giving poster and oral presentations, additional program elements, including developing a scientific hypothesis, emphasis on scientific communications, responsible conduct of research, professional development with GRE-prep and networking across sectors, help REU students gain a globalized perspective of real-world applications and the critical skills needed to develop into a "research scientist".  The new MultiTERM REU site has been extremely successful in the recruitment of qualified undergraduates with 73% of REU participants being women and 63% identified as under-represented minorities. Another broader impact is that 80% of our participants who have completed their undergraduate program, are currently attending/pursuing a graduate degree in STEM disciplines with all reporting ongoing strong interest in the TERM field and multidisciplinary, team-based research.
